items.description: South Cornwall coast at Mounts Bay, seafront properties
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected for seafront properties in Mounts Bay over all high tides from Sunday afternoon 28 October to Monday afternoon 30 October.   

High spring tides and a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels during this period. Forecast levels for Sunday evening are similar to Saturday evening, when flooding was observed in several locations. Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6 – 7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.   

High water at Newlyn is at16:49 Sunday, 05:09 & 17:28 Monday, local time. Times will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of high tides. Expect tides to be approximately 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.   

Moderate waves and spray are likely. Take care near the coast. There may be localised standing water on roads.  Do not drive through flood water or waves.   

Conditions should ease for Tuesday morning's high tide. We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates.

items.description: Tidal River Camel excluding Wadebridge and Chapel Amble
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected for areas within the Camel Estuary over the high tide on Sunday evening 29 October. 
High astronomical tides combined with a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels over the high tide, with levels being similar to those experienced last evening.  Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6 – 7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.   
High water at Padstow is at 17:28 on Sunday, time given in local time. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of the high tide. Expect tides to be around 500mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
Moderate waves are likely so take care near coastal paths and promenades. Do not drive through flood water or waves.  
Locations particularly at risk include the A389 at Sladesbridge and Padstow Harbour
The tidal gates at Padstow are closed.
Coastal conditions should ease for Monday morning’s high tide, however we are continuing to monitor the situation. Please check online for any updates to this message.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Saturday evening.
Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Clyst and Culm area. This has meant that the River Clyst is now rising. 
The main areas of concern are flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 7pm onwards on Saturday. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout today though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Monday evening or earlier if the situation changes

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

River levels continue to fall on the River Don. This alert remains in force as pumping operations are ongoing in the area to remove water that remains on low lying land and in washlands adjacent to the river. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Our incident room remains open, and we are closely monitoring the forecast. Further rain is forecast in the coming days and over the weekend, but no impacts are currently expected. We do not anticipate we will need to issue any further flood warnings at this stage.
The Jubilee Bridge flood gates have been opened and the Jubilee Bridge on Ferry Road in Thorne is now open. For a full list of roads that remain closed see the City of Doncaster Council website.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high, but are now receding. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message:

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Rame Head to Wembury Bay including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on all high tides from Sunday afternoon 29 October to Monday morning 30 October.  

High spring tides and a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels during this period. Forecast levels for Sunday evening are similar to Saturday evening when flooding was observed in several locations. Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6 – 7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.   

High water at Plymouth is 17:57 Sunday & 06:18 Monday, local time. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of high tide. Expect tides ~ 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

Moderate waves and spray are likely. Take care near the coast. There may be localised standing water on roads.  Do not drive through flood water or waves. Sutton Harbour Tidal Gates are closed.

Notter Bridge, Embankment Rd Plymouth, Torpoint Ferry Terminals and Noss Mayo are particularly at risk.
 
Conditions should ease for high tide Monday afternoon. We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for any updates.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on all high tides from Sun 29 - am Mon 30 Oct.

High tides & a large tidal surge will result in very high water levels during this period. Forecast levels for Sunday evening are similar to Saturday evening when flooding was observed in several locations. Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6–7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.

High water at Plymouth is 17:57 Sun & 06:18 Mon, local time. Time of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of high tides. Expect tides ~ 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

Moderate waves & spray are likely. Take care near the coast. There may be standing water on roads.  Do not drive through flood water or waves. Tidal gates at Polperro are closed.

Fowey Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay & Caffa Mill Car park, Lostwithiel Quay Street & Recreation ground, Polperro Harbour & Quay Rd, The Quay at Looe & the B3247 at Seaton are particularly at risk. 

Conditions should ease for high tide Mon pm. We are monitoring the situation. Please check online for updates

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening Sunday 29 October in Polperro.  
This Flood Alert has been activated by very high tidal levels in Polperro and not due to high fluvial river levels in this area. 
An exceptionally high tide last evening resulted in the levels in the River Pol being raised to Flood Alert levels in the lower part of the village. This is likely to occur again over the high tide period this evening Sunday 29 October when similar tidal levels to those observed last evening are forecast to be reached. High tide is around 17:43 local time this evening, so expect high water levels and associated flood risk up to 2 hours either side of high tide.
Flooding from rivers is not expected.
This message will be updated when the exceptionally high tidal levels fall below levels of concern, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected for Truro over high tide on Sunday evening 29 Oct.  
A high spring tide combined with a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels over the high tide period, with levels being similar to those observed last evening. 
High water at Truro is at 17:33 local time. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of the high tide. Expect tides to be around 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
Locations that may be affected include Newham Road, Garras Wharf including the Harbour Office, Malpas Road, Lemon Quay, Town Quay, Back Quay, Green Street, St Austell Street, Old Bridge Street, Festival Gardens, Boscowan Park and the A390
There may be standing water on roads.  Do not drive through flood water or waves.  
The tidal gates at Truro have been closed.
Coastal conditions should ease for Monday morning's high tide, however we are continuing to monitor the situation. Please check online for any updates to this message

items.description: South Cornwall Coast at Mounts Bay
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected for Mounts Bay over the high tide on Sunday evening 29 October.  
High spring tides and a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels over the high tide period. Levels are forecast to be similar to those last evening when flooding was observed in several locations. Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6 – 7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.   
The high tide at Newlyn is at 16:49 local time. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur up to 2 hours either side of the high tides. Expect tides to be around 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
Moderate waves and spray are likely so take care near coastal paths and promenades. This may cause localised standing water on roads. Do not drive through flood water or waves. 
Locations particularly at risk include parts of Marazion Marsh and Long Green.
Coastal conditions should ease for Monday morning’s high tide, however we are continuing to monitor the situation. Please check online for any updates to this message

items.description: South Cornwall coast at Mounts Bay, properties located behind the seafront
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected for properties located behind the sea front in Mounts Bay over the high tide on Sunday evening 29 Oct.   
High spring tides and a large tidal surge will result in significantly high water levels over the high tide period. Levels are forecast to be similar to those observed last evening. Offshore wave heights up to 5m combined with Force 6 – 7 winds may exacerbate any flooding.   

The high tide at Newlyn is at 16:49 local time. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Flooding may occur to properties in Mounts Bay up to 2 hours either side of high tide. Expect tides to be around 600mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
Moderate waves and spray are likely so take care near coastal paths and promenades. This may cause localised standing water on roads. Do not drive through flood water or waves. 
Locations particularly at risk include Newlyn, Penzance, Longrock and Marazion
Coastal conditions should ease for Monday morning’s high tide, however we are continuing to monitor the situation. Please check online for any updates to this message

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message:
Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.
